intro: Gilia eremica var. typica, commonly known as the desert gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its slender, branching stems and showy, pink to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in arid and semi-arid environments, such as sandy soils and rocky slopes. Its flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators like bees and butterflies. The species is adapted to withstand drought conditions, making it a resilient plant in harsh desert climates.
